The main differential diagnosis is melanoma. This is the main question asked when examining a patient: is this pigmented lesion a simple nevus or an incipient melanoma?

Other differential diagnoses are as follows:

- Seborrheic keratosis

- Histiocytofibroma

- Basal cell carcinoma

- Actinic lentigo

- Botriomycome

- Thombosed angioma

- Plantar hematic lesion

question.title: Question
question.description: What is a common differential diagnosis for a pigmented lesion that is being examined to distinguish from a simple nevus or an incipient melanoma?

option_a.title: Option A
option_a.description: A type of benign skin tumor that can appear as a pigmented lesion

option_b.title: Option B
option_b.description: A condition characterized by the presence of multiple small, pigmented spots on the skin, often seen in sun-exposed areas

option_c.title: Option C
option_c.description: A rare skin cancer that typically appears as a small, flesh-colored bump on the skin

option_d.title: Option D
option_d.description: A type of benign skin lesion that is often seen in children and is characterized by a thick, scaly crust
